Democratic Republic of Timor-Leste: Infrastructure

In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  Timor-Leste has requested assistance from the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to help 
coordinate capacity development and investment planning across infrastructure and to mobilize 
financial resources needed for infrastructure investment. The technical assistance (TA) will 
respond to this request by helping Timor-Leste prepare and begin implementation of a long-term 
strategic plan for its Ministry of Public Works (MPW). Fact-finding took place in October 2012.1 
The  government  has  concurred  with  the  TA’s  impact,  outcome,  outputs,  implementation 
arrangements,  cost,  financing  arrangements,  and  terms  of  reference.  The  design  and 
monitoring framework of the TA is in Appendix 1. 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Timor-Leste has initiated a new development phase based on converting revenue from 
offshore petroleum into human and physical capital. Efforts are being guided by the Timor-Leste 
Strategic  Development  Plan  (SDP),  2011–2030.  The  plan  identifies  an  ambitious  list  of 
infrastructure projects, and calls for the front-loading of implementation during its first 5 years.2 
A  national  electrification  program  is  nearing  completion, two  additional  telecommunications 
operators have been licensed to expand telecommunication services and reduce prices, and 
major investments are under way or in preparation for most other infrastructure sectors. More 
than $3 billion in infrastructure investment has been budgeted for 2012–2017.3 
3.  The surge in infrastructure investment is placing large demands on the government’s 
infrastructure agencies and their qualified staff, who are in short supply. At the same time, 
Timor-Leste has embarked on an assertive upgrading of human capacity through additional 
skills. The departure of experienced Timorese for further studies has the immediate effect of 
adding to skill shortages.  
4.  The government is outsourcing key activities to ensure that infrastructure services are 
delivered despite capacity shortages within government agencies. Outsourcing is made feasible 
by the financial resources provided by petroleum revenue, and is essential if the development 
goals  of  the  SDP  are  to  be  achieved.  The  SDP  provides  for  the  use  of  public–private 
partnerships (PPPs) where they offer value for money; the PPP policy and law are in place, and 
pathfinder PPPs are in preparation. 
5.  Reforms  have  been  made  to  facilitate  the  surge  in  infrastructure  investment.  The 
Conselho de Administração do Fundo Infraestrutura (infrastructure fund council), chaired by the 
Prime Minister and including key ministers, has been established to provide overall leadership 
to  infrastructure.  The  council’s  secretariat—the  Major  Projects  Secretariat—oversees  new 
business processes adopted for major projects. The secretariat also has a planning role for the 
infrastructure sectors, is responsible for PPPs, and is the executing agency for all loan-financed 
projects. The procurement of projects costing more than $1 million is the responsibility of the 
new National Procurement Commission, which is assisted by an independent procurement 
agent, and the recently established National Development Agency is engaged in the approval 
and quality control of infrastructure projects.  
6.  Under the new business processes, line agencies implement major projects, and have 
added responsibilities for mid-sized projects (i.e., projects costing from $0.25 million to $1

million).4 To improve efficiency, in July 2012 the Ministry of Infrastructure was separated into 
two ministries: the MPW and the Ministry of Transport and Communications. 
7.  Development partners have responded by aligning their activities with the SDP and 
scaling up by their support for infrastructure. ADB’s country partnership strategy, 2011–2015 is 
helping the government fast-track development by supporting the upgrade of the country’s 
infrastructure and complementary initiatives.5 Other key development partners in infrastructure 
include the Australian Agency for International Development (AusAID), the European Union, the 
International Finance Corporation, Japan International Cooperation Agency, the United Nations 
Development Programme, and the World Bank. 
8.  The  government’s  new  approach  to  major  projects  is  still  being  refined.  There  is 
considerable room for improvement via the clarification of sector plans and the responsibilities 
of agencies, and by streamlining project preparation (e.g., combining approvals) and key steps 
in  project  administration  (e.g.,  the  processing  of  contractor  claims).  The  expansion  in 
development support is creating extra demands by bringing their systems and processes into 
use. In keeping with the international commitments to aid effectiveness, these need to be 
integrated with the new government systems. For example, project management units need to 
be seamlessly integrated within ministries, and potential conflicts in procurement practices need 
to  be  avoided.  In  this  increasingly  complex  environment,  a  clear  vision  of  best  practices, 
processes, and systems is needed to ensure sound infrastructure investment. 
9.  These rapid changes are taking place against a record of poor sustainability. Many 
rehabilitated assets have fallen into disrepair well before the end of their design life. Unless 
sustainability is improved, some of the current surge in investment spending may be wasted. 
Achieving sustainability will rest on the strengthening of government agencies, building the 
capacity of their staff, ensuring adequate recurrent cost financing and sound operating and 
maintenance practices, and securing broad ownership of new initiatives.  
10.  The  major  road  upgrades  supported  by  development  partners  include  extended 
maintenance contracts, thereby outsourcing this essential function. With ADB support, a short 
period of operation and maintenance is being combined with the upgrade of the water and 
sanitation systems in two district capitals. While these approaches offer quick solutions, a long-
term solution is still needed. 
11.  The governance arrangements for the providers of power, water and sanitation, port, 
and airport services are a further challenge. Service providers lack the autonomy needed to 
operate along business lines; e.g., they are dependent on the government budget for funding, 
staff are employed under standard civil service arrangements, and regulatory and operating 
roles are yet to be separated. Some operate as sections of a ministry. Modernized management 
approaches  that  provide  incentives  for  and  an  ability  to  achieve  efficiency  improvements, 
subject to checks and balances, would increase the returns from the facilities they manage. 
12.  Although the need for TA for infrastructure agencies is increasing, key ADB TA projects 
are winding down: Infrastructure Project Management; Strengthening Major Public Investments 
(which supports the Major Projects Secretariat); and the Results-Based Project Management for 
Pacific Developing Member Countries.6 Even with the ADB TA for Strengthening Water Sector

13.  The new investment projects supported by development partners can meet some of the 
needs. For example, they can provide opportunities for on-the-job training for inexperienced 
professionals, and trial ways of streamlining of systems and processes. Externally supported 
projects  have  a key  role  to  play  as  a  catalyst  of  change.  But  such support  needs  to  be 
complemented  by  a  higher-level,  strategic  perspective  that  provides  overall  guidance  to 
infrastructure management. This complementary support can only be provided through TA, 
which  is  essential  to  ensure  that  the  surge  in  infrastructure  investment  will  meet  quality 
standards, provide value for money, and be sustainable. 
14.  The TA will strengthen the higher-level systems and processes needed for effective and 
sustainable infrastructure management. The TA will help the MPW prepare a long-term strategic 
plan that will set out the results targeted in the road transport, water and sanitation, and power 
sectors, and how these targets will be achieved. The plan will emphasize capacity development. 
Assistance will also be provided to guide implementation and monitoring of the strategy.  
15.  The TA will be the first of two phases of support. The proposed second phase will 
support implementation of priority initiatives of the MPW strategic plan, and will be prepared as 
the strategic plan nears completion. The second phase will also consider replicating the support 
in other infrastructure agencies where assistance is needed. 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
16.  The impact will be the delivery of sustainable roads and bridges, water and sanitation, 
and  power  infrastructure.  Performance  will  be  measured  by  budget  execution  rates,  the 
provision of adequate funds for maintenance of major roads, and the initiation of infrastructure 
PPPs. The outcome will be strengthened infrastructure management by the MPW. Performance 
will be measured by progress in implementing the long-term strategic plan for the MPW, which 
will be prepared with the support of the TA. 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
17.  The TA will provide two outputs: (i) a long-term, results-based strategic plan for the 
MPW,  and  (ii)  an  operational  capacity  development  framework.  The  strategic  plan  will  be 
concluded by the end of 2013, and will integrate the capacity development framework. The TA 
will subsequently support the initial implementation and monitoring of the strategic plan and the 
capacity development framework. The TA will focus on infrastructure investments larger than 
$0.25 million. 
18.  The MPW strategic plan will help implement the Timor-Leste SDP and the MPW action

plan for 2013–2017 prepared in response to the program of the fifth constitutional government.8 
The SDP and MPW action plan focus on what is to be done, and provide only general guidance 
on how it will be done. They need to be backed up by a management approach focused on 
resolving hurdles to success in implementation and in achieving sustainability. This will be put in 
place through the MPW strategic plan. 
19.  The MPW strategic plan will articulate the major development challenges and desired 
results for roads and bridges, water and sanitation, and power. It will identify sector priorities, 
and spell out in broad terms the projects, programs, and other interventions needed to achieve 
the priorities. Gaps that need to be filled will be identified. For example, the MPW strategic plan 
is expected to identify the system changes needed to make investment sustainable (e.g., the 
establishment of maintenance regimes, independent management structures for utilities, and 
user charging policies).  
20.  The capacity development framework is a critical input to the MPW strategic plan. To 
give sufficient emphasis to capacity development, it will be prepared through a separate but 
linked  process.  The  framework  will  set  out  how  the  MPW  and  its  staff  can  develop  the 
knowledge,  abilities,  and  systems  necessary  to  implement  a  results-based  management 
approach and improve performance. It will help staff develop new capacities that will allow them 
to cope with change at a personal level and empower them to be part of a new, higher 
performance agency. A baseline assessment of capacity and a map of the sequenced actions 
required  to  help  agencies  and  individual  staff  achieve  the  target  level  of  capacity  will  be 
provided. 
21.  Progress against the MPW strategic plan and the capacity development framework will 
be  reported  publicly  to  enhance  the  public  accountability  of  infrastructure  investment  and 
facilitate the engagement of external stakeholders. The frameworks will provide a vehicle to 
incorporate key issues into infrastructure planning, such as the achievement of gender equity. 
They  will  also  provide  a  focus  for  development  coordination  to  improve  alignment  and 
harmonization  in  the  infrastructure  sectors,  with  all  development  partners  encouraged  to 
participate in their preparation and application. 
22.  Key assumptions of the TA include strong ownership and input by the MPW and other 
infrastructure agencies in preparing a strategic plan for the MPW, and the capacity of the 
government’s  planning  and  budget  systems  to  accommodate  results-based  management 
approaches.  The  TA  also  assumes  that  a  consensus  will  emerge  on  the  best  long-term 
approach to capacity development, and that stakeholders including development partners are 
actively engaged. The key risks are that high project workloads will divert attention from new 
management  approaches,  and  that  new  approaches  to  infrastructure  management  prove 
difficult to integrate with established operating practices. 
C.  Cost and Financing 
23.  The TA is estimated to cost $510,000, of which $500,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-IV). The government will provide 
counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff and office accommodation and other in-kind 
contributions. A cost estimate and financing plan is provided in Appendix 2.

D.  Implementation Arrangements 
24.  The MPW, through its Directorate of Corporate Services, will be the executing agency. 
The MPW will provide overall guidance to the TA and ensure alignment with the government’s 
plans. ADB will be the implementing agency. ADB’s Special Office in Timor-Leste will be the 
focal point for the TA and be responsible for coordinating TA activities on a day-to-day basis.  
25.  The TA will require up to 38 person-months of consulting services, provided by a team 
leader (national, full-time, 24 person-months), a capacity development adviser (international, 
intermittent, 4 person-months), a results-based management adviser (international, intermittent, 
4 person-months), and engineer(s) (national, intermittent, total of 6 person-months). The team 
leader will establish reporting and coordination arrangements with the MPW. The two advisers 
will provide most of their input by the end of 2013, and return periodically to Timor-Leste to 
assist  in  implementation  and  monitoring.  Outline  terms  of  reference  for  the  individual 
consultants are in Appendix 3. 
26.  To  provide  for  flexibility  and  timeliness  in  recruitment,  international  and  national 
consultants will be selected and engaged by ADB on an individual basis in accordance with its 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). Disbursements 
under the TA will be  made in accordance with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement 
Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). 
27.  The TA will collaborate with other development partner activities, most notably those of 
AusAID,  Japan  International  Cooperation  Agency,  the  World  Bank,  and  the  International 
Finance Corporation. A coordination committee, cochaired by the key infrastructure agencies 
and development partners, will be established to guide support for capacity development and 
results-based  management  in  the  infrastructure  sectors.  The  team  leader  will  assist  this 
coordination committee by acting as its secretariat. Where elements of the MPW strategic plan 
are being put in place or implemented through other development assistance, such as ADB 
support for the water and sanitation sector, the TA will play a secondary role. 
28.  The TA will support awareness-raising events for stakeholders within government and 
public awareness-raising events for stakeholders outside government. These events will provide 
an opportunity to explain TA activities to stakeholders; receive feedback on performance; and 
disseminate  good  practices,  knowledge  products,  and  lessons.  The  government  website, 
notably the Timor-Leste Transparency Portal, will also be used as a key vehicle for information 
dissemination.9 To assist monitoring and evaluation, quarterly updates on TA progress and 
issues will be submitted by the team leader to the MPW and ADB. Other partners supporting 
related initiatives will be invited to participate in the midterm and final reviews of the TA. 
29.  The TA will commence on 15 January 2013 and be completed on 31 December 2014. 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION  
 
30.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Timor-Leste for Infrastructure Management and hereby reports this action to 
the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Overview 
 
1.  The technical assistance (TA) consultants will help the Ministry of Public Works (MPW) 
prepare a long-term strategic plan that will set out results targeted in the road transport, water 
and  sanitation,  and  power  sectors,  and  how these targets  will  be  achieved.  The  plan  will 
emphasize  capacity  development.  The  TA  consultants  will  also  help  the  MPW  guide 
implementation and monitoring of the strategy. 
2.  Support for preparing the strategic plan will draw on the successful trial of the managing 
for development results approach with the National Directorate for Water Supply of the Ministry 
of Infrastructure.1 The TA consultants will help the MPW work with other line agencies and 
central agencies engaged in infrastructure in a process developed through the TA for Results-
Based Project Management for Pacific Developing Member Countries.2  
3.  The TA consultants will support adoption of a broad concept of capacity development, 
such as that presented in the Practical Guide to Capacity Development in a Sector Context of 
the Asian Development Bank (ADB), which describes capacity development as the process of 
changing toward results.3 The guide highlights that, as capacity development takes place in 
people and organizations, it has to be owned and cannot be imposed on them. In addition, as 
capacity  development  must  arise  from  the  environment  or  from  internal  factors,  external 
partners cannot ―do‖ capacity development of others; they can only support or help to create the 
right external incentives for capacity development processes. 
4.  The TA consultants will draw on the capacity development framework outlined in Closing 
Capacity Gaps in Timor-Leste, specifically the six steps to capacity development.4 It will also 
draw on the insights from the staged capacity building model of the Australian Agency for 
International  Development  (AusAID).5 The  capacity  development  framework  will  pay  close 
attention  to  lessons  from  ADB  assistance  to  Timor-Leste,  including  those  from  AusAID’s 
independent review of the Infrastructure Project Management TA.6 
                                                
1  Managing for development results helps organizations align internal policies, practice, and behavior with targeted 
external results. The approach can be separated into three stages: (i) being clear about the results that an 
organization has to deliver, the problems that face it, and the gaps in its performance; (ii) identification of the 
changes an organization has to make to deliver results’ and (iii) implementation of a change management process, 
which is monitored to improve the management of the organization and to improve performance. This work is 
discussed  in  ADB.  2011.  Results-Based  Project  Management  for  Pacific  Developing  Member  Countries. 
Consultant’s report. Manila (TA 6436-REG; mission report for February and April 2011).

B.  Terms of Reference 
1.  Team Leader (national, full-time, 24 person-months) 
5.  The team leader will hold overall responsibility for TA implementation. The team leader 
will have a postgraduate degree in management, public policy, international development, or a 
related field, and at least 5 years experience in results-based management approaches and 
capacity development in the public or private sectors. Fluency in Tetun and English is essential. 
Knowledge of Portuguese and a background in infrastructure are highly desirable. 
6.  The team leader will have overall responsibility for the delivery of TA outputs, notably the 
MPW long-term strategic plan and a capacity development framework. The team leader will 
ensure the TA supports a government-led process that ensures strong local ownership of these 
outputs. Other tasks will include the following: 
(i)  taking responsibility for the overall development and implementation of the TA 
under the guidance of the MPW, including coordination, capacity development 
and  training,  communication,  information  sharing,  and  dialogue  with  senior 
members of government and stakeholders; 
(ii)  establishing reporting arrangements to the MPW, and ensuring they are followed 
throughout the TA; 
(iii)  coordinating the inputs of the results-based management adviser and capacity 
development  adviser  in  supporting  the  preparation,  implementation,  and 
monitoring of the MPW strategic plan and capacity development framework; 
(iv)  assisting  the  MPW  to  compile  regular  reports  on  progress  in  preparing, 
implementing,  and  monitoring  of  the  MPW  strategic  plan  and  capacity 
development framework; 
(v)  supporting the MPW in establishing an effective communication system that will 
raise the awareness of government and external stakeholders on results-based 
management  and  capacity  development,  including  through  the  conduct  of 
seminars, workshops, and preparing knowledge products and other information 
releases; 
(vi)  facilitating dialogue events with stakeholders in support of TA implementation, 
including training, seminars, conferences, and workshops; and 
(vii)  transferring  skills  and  building  the  capacity  of  the  MPW  in  results-based 
management and capacity development. 
 
7.  In addition, the team leader will 
(i)  lead  the  TA  implementation  in  accordance  with  the  terms  and  conditions 
specified in the agreement between the government and ADB;  
(ii)  coordinate and manage the inputs, activities, and outputs of TA consultants, 
including the allocation of responsibilities between consultants, the administration 
of all contracts under the TA, and monitoring the performance of all consultants;  
(iii)  manage TA resources to achieve the results sought by the design and monitoring 
framework, including initiating and leading discussions of key implementation 
issues  with  the  government,  and  managing  TA  quality  control  and  quality 
assurance;  
(iv)  organize TA inception and concluding workshops with senior representatives of 
the government, government officials, and other relevant stakeholders to inform 
the preparation and/or review of TA;

Appendix 3  11 
(v)  prepare and monitor progress against a risk management plan that will identify 
key risks to sustainability and the actions required to minimize these risks;  
(vi)  ensure  timely  preparation  and  submission  of  the  inception  report,  monthly 
progress reports, the midterm report, and the project completion report, and 
assist with TA reviews undertaken by ADB and the government; and 
(vii)  consult with development partners on TA activities, ensuring that development 
partners are frequently informed of activities and that a high level of coordination 
is maintained that avoids duplication or overlap of work. 
2.  Results-Based Management Adviser (international, intermittent, 4 person-
months) 
8.  The adviser will report to the MPW through the team leader. The adviser will have a 
postgraduate degree in management, public policy, or a related field, and at least 10 years 
experience  in  results-based  management  approaches  in  the  public  or  private  sectors.  A 
background in infrastructure is highly desirable. Fluency in English is essential.  
9.  The adviser will have the lead technical role in supporting the adoption of results-based 
management approaches in the preparation and implementation of the MPW long-term strategic 
plan. The support will build on the successful trial of the managing for development results 
approach with the National Directorate for Water Supply of MPW, and follow the manuals 
prepared by the TA for Results-Based Project Management in Pacific Developing Member 
Countries (footnote 2). 
10.  Specific tasks will include 
(i)  assisting the  MPW to clarify target results,  the  problems faced  in  delivering 
results, and gaps in performance; 
(ii)  assisting the MPW to identify the changes needed to ensure the agency can 
deliver target results; 
(iii)  assisting the MPW to map out a change management process; 
(iv)  supporting  the  finalization  by  the  MPW  of  time-bound  results  frameworks 
inclusive of targets, indicators, and baselines; 
(v)  monitoring the implementation of the MPW strategic plan; and 
(vi)  undertaking other tasks as required by the team leader, and as may be required 
for successful TA implementation. 
11.  In  undertaking  these  tasks,  the  adviser  is  expected  to  (i)  engage  in  briefings  and 
seminars with senior members of government and stakeholders to share experiences and 
disseminate  information  on  results-based  management,  (ii)  advise  on  the  preparation  of 
knowledge  products  on  results-based  management,  and  (iii)  transfer  skills  and  build  the 
capacity of the infrastructure agencies in implementing results-based management approaches. 
3.  Capacity Development Adviser (international, intermittent, 4 person-months) 
12.  The adviser will report to the MPW through the team leader. The adviser will have a 
postgraduate degree in management, public policy, or a related field, and at least 10 years 
experience  in  results-based  management  approaches  in  the  public  or  private  sectors.  A 
background in infrastructure is highly desirable. Fluency in English is essential.

12  Appendix 3 
 
13.  The adviser will have the lead technical role in supporting the preparation and monitoring 
of a capacity development framework for the MPW. The support will follow the six steps to 
capacity development outlined in  Closing Capacity Gaps in Timor-Leste, and draw on the 
insights from AusAID’s staged capacity building model (footnote 4). The support will also pay 
close  attention  to  lessons  from  ADB’s  assistance  to  Timor-Leste,  in  particular  those  from 
AusAID’s independent review of the Infrastructure Project Management TA. 
14.  Specific tasks will include 
(i)  facilitating the identification of stakeholders relevant to capacity development; 
(ii)  assisting the MPW to define capacity needs and analyze the state of capacity, 
inclusive of preparation of a baseline capacity assessment; 
(iii)  facilitate the formulation by the MPW of approaches to closing capacity gaps; 
(iv)  assisting the MPW to prepare strategies for safeguarding service delivery while 
capacity is built; 
(v)  supporting the finalization of a time-bound, results-based capacity development 
framework for the MPW inclusive of targets, indicators, and a baseline, and 
assisting in its integration with the MPW long-term strategic plan; 
(vi)  monitoring the implementation of the capacity development framework; and 
(vii)  undertaking other tasks as required by the team leader, and as may be required 
for successful TA implementation. 
15.  In undertaking these specific tasks, the adviser is expected to (i) engage in briefings and 
seminars with senior members of government and stakeholders to share experiences and 
disseminate information on capacity development, (ii) advise on the preparation of knowledge 
products  on  capacity  development,  and  (iii)  transfer  skills  and  build  the  capacity  of  the 
infrastructure agencies in implementing capacity development. 
4.  Engineers (as required) (national, intermittent, total of 6 person-months) 
16.  The engineers should have an engineering degree (mechanical, electrical, structural, 
civil or architecture as required for particular inputs to be determined) with minimum 5 years 
engineering, project and/or contract administration experience. Work experience in a public 
agency and design and contract administration project experience are required. Fluency in 
Tetun is essential, and a good understanding of English or Portuguese is highly desirable. The 
engineers will have a degree from a recognized university (national or international). 
17.  Reporting to the team leader, the engineers will provide specialist technical expertise 
needed to support preparation of the MPW’s long-term strategic plan and capacity development 
framework. The scope of work will be determined once skill gaps are identified and prioritized by 
the team leader. Assistance is expected to cover the business processes and policies of the 
MPW  in  relation  to  project  preparation,  procurement,  project  implementation,  and  project 
monitoring and evaluation; and staff training. 
C.  Reporting Requirements 
 
18.  The team leader will be responsible for the quality of all reports, documentation, and 
submissions produced under the TA to a publishable and high professional standard. All reports 
required  to  explain  and  assess  TA  activities  are  to  be  in  English  and  suitable  for  public

Appendix 3  13 
circulation. With the support of TA consultants, the team leader will submit an inception report, 
quarterly progress reports, a midterm report, a draft final report, and a final report to the 
government and ADB.  
(i)  Inception  report.  The  inception  report  will  provide  a  clear  plan  for  TA 
implementation, challenges to its success, and a summary of the status of TA 
performance. It will, to the extent feasible, provide (a) confirmation of the overall 
TA  rationale  and  design;  or  (b)  adjustments  recommended  to  improve  TA 
performance,  including  to  the  terms  of  reference  of  consultants;  and  (c)  a 
detailed TA implementation schedule. 
(ii)  Quarterly  progress  reports. These brief reports (maximum of 5 pages) will 
inform the government and ADB of the status of implementing the terms of 
reference and immediate plans for advancing the TA objectives. These reports 
will adopt a uniform format to facilitate monitoring. 
(iii)  Midterm report. The midterm report will inform the government and ADB of the 
status  of  implementing  the  terms  of  reference,  plans  for  achieving  the  TA 
objectives, and a personnel schedule with accomplishments under each item of 
the design and monitoring framework. This report will record activities, outputs, 
and outcomes directly against the TA design and monitoring framework. It will 
provide (a) confirmation of the TA overall rationale and design; or (b) adjustments 
recommended to improve TA performance, including to the terms of reference of 
consultants; and (c) a detailed TA implementation schedule. 
(iv)  Draft final report. The draft final report will (a) be submitted 2 months prior to TA 
completion, (b) summarize TA activities and results, reporting against the design 
and monitoring framework, and (c) provide recommendations on any additional 
steps required to sustain the results of the TA. 
(v)  Final report. The final report will be submitted by the consultants within 1 month 
of receipt of the comments on the draft final report from the government and 
ADB, and will respond to the comments received.
